They literally do not practice what they teach. Learning Management System isn't consistent or well implemented. IT is dismal and needs funding. Some facilities and operations are ancient and sad. Some of the academic leadership (everyone knows who they are) are some of the rudest, most pompous windbags you'll ever meet. They belittle their own staff, backstab others, refuse to fall in line behind the expertise of others who are trying to turn things around, yet they are still there, year after year. They are only happy when they are catered too, and only until the next request.

pros: Employee Tuition Reimbursement, some great staff. Made several connections with non-toxic staff members.
cons: This going to be a long post so I apologize in advance. Upper management in the Admissions area has gone downhill fast. They are trying to look under every rug to find a student. We are becoming a for profit institution. They’ve bullied people out of positions just to hire their frat buddies yet they try to promote themselves as being diverse. They held a large scholarship event promising students money to only turn around and say “no we won’t give anyone money” until faculty gets upset. They give away pity little amounts to try and make themselves look good. What a joke. The head “hauncho” in charge is not a nice person. He doesn’t care about anyone else’s time but his and will work you to death just to try and make himself look good for the board of trustees and president. This is a guy that literally does nothing but work and work and even told several of us how proud he is of what he does and even missed his children’s birthdays and their school events because his ego is that big! I have a family that I value and I value the time I get to spend with them. However, now this person is wanting people to work weekends (staff that don’t even work in Admissions). This wasn’t in my job description when I started. Do we have to use our vacation time on the weekends now? Is that now a requirement? If you look at this place, please please please look elsewhere. There is a major employee turnover problem and student retention is low. They care about their numbers and getting people in the door, but lose their “care” about them once they start the academic year. I’m not stating my role for fear of retaliation because I believe it would go that far with the current person in charge. The guy had a 22 page resume! He goes from job to job and will leave any prior institution a wreck. The board of trustees is just to blame for hiring such a careless and cold hearted individual. To add a cherry on top, there is no cost of living increases. I can barely afford to work. They did a measly compensation study to find they underpaid employees yet even after their little study, they still underpay you! If you enjoy your life, look elsewhere. As a former undergraduate student in Regis College with a now MBA and employee, I’ve seen this place go so far down hill I don’t think it can save itself. The reputation has been tarnished. It upsets me so much that Regis has gone in this direction. I used to love my job and my time here as a student, but working here is toxic. Do not drink the kool aid!

pros: The list of pros has unfortunately gone way downhill. The only pros I can see are the employee tuition benefits. However, it may not be worth your time waiting for it to kick in after 6 months. You may have already left by then!
cons: This list on the other hand is endless and grows day by day. New leadership within the Admissions and Financial Aid Offices at Regis has gone downhill to the point where we aim to set goals a for profit school seeks, but with a non profit designation. That is not how it works! In fact, one of the new leaders came from a for profit school that ended up shutting its doors! The newest leader, someone that likes to use their title a lot, (hint hint not an MD), likes to over work his employees and is now requiring more staff to attend these absurd weekend events which were never required in the past. They do not value your time and will try to eat you alive. There is no rhyme or reason to what happens, it’s literally hour by hour something will change. It’s so poorly lead now which is such a shame given how prestigious Regis used to be. I would advise to stay far away from this place. If you value family time and your own time, this is most definitely not the place for you. With all of the money that is being spent though, this place may not be around for much longer. As an added bonus too, they will also not raise compensation for cost of living, which is sky high in the Denver metro area. The school also has a major employee and student retention problem. They claim to have a mission, but it is twisted, delusional, one-sided with so many double standards it’s not even funny.

review_title: Low Pay, Apathetic Leaders, Disorganization On All Levels
pros: Pretty campus. Working from home was great while it lasted. Friendly students.
cons: I’ve worked for 2 other universities in the past and this was by far the most disorganized/political ego mess of a school I’ve ever been a part of. Red flags were apparent very early on. I noticed VERY high turnover in the first few months I was there as well. I received no training and was left to figure out things for myself for the most part. Zero team morale - felt like everyone was there for a paycheck and could care less about getting to know me. While some co–workers in other departments were friendly, I never felt as though I was part of a supportive or friendly team myself. Meetings with other departments were always full of questions and never understanding who was responsible for what. Just absolute chaos. On top of that, pay was much lower than expected or deserved. The icing on the cake was when I gave my 2 weeks notice after accepting another position, only to be ignored without so much as a “thanks for your time and help so far” from a single supervisor. How childish, rude and unprofessional can you get?

review_title: there are few workplaces where you will see monks, this is one of them.
pros:
They are Catholic (Jesuit) but they don't discriminate if you have different beliefs. I am a Freemason and Masons and Catholics tend not to get along (at least historically) but it was never an issue at Regis. I was very impressed with the school itself and their high standards and they value morals and ethics in a general enough way as to not be prescriptive about religion. For example, when I was there they gave everyone an extra day off work if you went out and did something charitable (where this day did not come out of vacation or sick leave)--I think other businesses should adopt this practice. 

The job stress level was also very low and they were very sensitive to burn out. I would definitely recommend Regis to both potential students and potential employees. If you are going as a teacher: They told me they don't do tenure and you don't get the summer session off since they are on a quarterly schedule instead of the semester schedule; however, their increased pay more than makes up for it. 

Oh, and about the monks. I come out of my office one day and see a dozen monks with shaved heads and robes walking around the school. And no, it was not Halloween, they were actual monks. That was very cool.
cons: Since Regis is a private school, I think their budget got a bit pinched by the recession so there may not be as many openings as there were before 2008. I am not certain on this, just guessing because I need 20 words here and I can't think of any other cons.

review_title: Low Pay, Bad Benefits, Technologically Backward, Racism is actively tolerated here
pros: There a lot of wonderful faculty who strive to give their students the best experiences. More university holidays than other private universities. The mentor program is a good opportunity for professional growth, although it isn't paid work. Great spoken values that sadly are rarely reflected in practice.
cons: I have never seen an administrative failure quite like Regis. No one has what they need to make this university the best it can be for the students, and executive leadership doesn't seem to care. They refuse to even consider integrating systems to streamline processes because it would cost too much money upfront. Meanwhile, staff salaries are so low, more than half  of the staff who are full-time work a second job. The health benefits are expensive, PTO benefits are stingy, and the tuition benefits pales in comparison to what the other Colorado private schools have to offer.  The worst part of the university in my opinion is the Provost. She has consistently failed her staff in numerous ways and never tries to make things better. She has said many racist things and is never held accountable. It seems that the executive leadership at Regis will do anything to hush incidents of racism including silencing those who speak up. Overall a demoralizing environment and no leadership will speak up to fix the things that make it that way.

pros: The Regis campus is an arboretum, so it has lots of pretty trees and nice places to sit and relax. They have an awesome employee tuition benefit (3 classes a semester @ $25 a credit) and your kids and spouse can attend school under the benefit. They give you 40 hours of "mission leave" where you basically get paid by Regis to volunteer in the community. You have lots of freedom to manage your work or not do your work, since nobody is micromanaging you.
cons: The pay is low and promotions are hard to come by. There are no employee evaluations, so it's easy for people to not pull their weight. You'll likely do work outside of your job description (and pay grade) and not receive any kind of recognition or pay increase/job title change. You'll notice a lot of "old timers" who have been there awhile and are pretty difficult to work with. There's basically a lot of mismanagement and some unethical practices among institutional leaders. I've seen 22+ people leave Regis in my 2.5 years.Their IT infrastructure is terrible-- it will hinder you from being able to do your job. And unless you have a PhD, you'll be treated like an imbecile.

review_title: Low salaries and no professional development; dysfunctional, top-down, politically-focused leadership - need I say more?
pros: Benefits are good. Mission of the university is inspiring when carried out. Working with and for students and seeing them take action to positively impact the world is fulfilling and fun. There is understanding about needing to take time off for family emergencies, illness, bereavement. Non-management personnel are some of the nicest people I have ever worked with. Campus is a beautiful place to work.
cons: Leadership decisions are politically motivated and not well-informed. Management is top-down, non-transparent and overbearing. Takes a long time for decisions to be made because every major issue requires a committee to come to a consensus and those on the committees are there for political reasons and not because of experience relevant to the issue. Waste a lot of money paying outside "experts" because they don't trust the expertise they have in house already. Pay is below market average and official HR policy is there is no personal development and no telecommuting. No performance reviews and no raises except for a university-wide 2% raise in the fall which has been cancelled more than 50% of my time here due to financial instability. Very difficult to move up and join the leadership clique. Parking is horrible. Employee morale is currently very low due to two rounds of layoffs in 2014. Most likely there are more to come. Depressing work environment with fear for keeping your job.

review_title: Small liberal-arts college with a friendly atmosphere.
pros: Open minded and intelligent atmosphere.  Beautiful campus with a classic academic feel.  It really does feel good to go to work here every day. Educational benefits for yourself and family are a big plus. The new administration (as of fall, 2012) seems to be working hard at building unifying goals and reducing the "silo" effect. I am not Catholic and feel very welcome on campus and in my job.  They are great about making spiritual and Catholic resources available to their faculty, staff and students, but it never ever feels pushy. It is just there if you want it; no big deal if you don't.
cons: Within the departments, management training is slim to none.  The chairs are PhDs in their field and teachers, not managers.  Most mean well, but have little idea as to how to manage people or lead effectively and sometimes this leads to difficulties.  As with many not-for-profit environments, faculty and staff are constantly being asked to do more with less, promotions are hard to come by and the pay is somewhat less than average for comparable positions. For me, for now, the pros well outweigh the cons.

pros:
There are a lot of good people who want to make Regis a better place for its employees and students.

The campus is a wonderful oasis from the urban environment it is surrounded by.

The tuition benefit is a great employee perk.

If you show competence you will be rewarded with additional responsibilities.
cons:
For a small school, it is heavily siloed because of different departments that value their power over actual collaboration and growth.

Senior leadership consistently fails to communicate properly with its stakeholders of students, employees, and faculty.

There is no formal employee review process by HR.

If you show competence you will be rewarded with additional responsibilities without being compensated.

There is a stunning lack of diversity within staff and faculty and this perpetuates the stale operational practices of the University.

Once you get a degree you will likely depart for pay and benefits that reflect the actual standard for living in Denver and its suburbs.

You have to pay for on-campus parking as an employee.

review_title: Find someplace else unless you are desperate
pros: The tuition is free which is a big plus, and it is a beautiful campus which is very nice. But...
cons:
If you love working in a highly cliqueish environment where the in crowd routinely sandbags those they don't like then this is the place for you! And I mean don't like, just like in middle school, doesn't have anything to do with job performance. If you want to know who the in crowd is just check who has worked there the longest. Vindictiveness for the sake of something to feel powerful about is the rule.

Someone elses review compared it to Survivor, which made me chuckle because that is an accurate description! People are routinely voted off the island and I have a sneaking suspicion the reason is because they are in fact GOOD AT THEIR JOBS. Which means they are a threat to the old guard who are incompetent at best. Look at the student reviews, not the five star ones because those are fake.

pros: Name recognition; a long history in the community and a very pleasant campus environment.
cons: The institution is simply not run on the values and ethics that it purports to have. I had originally thought that despite a very low salary (I took a pay cut to work there), it would be rewarding to work for a Catholic organization, especially being Catholic myself. Unfortunately, the president of the university at the time really undermined that opinion. Leadership overall, particularly in University Relations, was really lacking. They spent money and wasted time filling positions as favors to friends and donors and were very submissive to the archbishop of Denver. Overall, I think the experience could vary greatly, depending on which area of the university you work. University Relations is a mess and everyone talks about it but nobody does anything to fix the issues.

pros: Paid time off, tuition benefits
cons: Calls themselves a mission  driven university, yet does not practice anything that they preach. Leadership within admissions is garbage, and treats employees like they are underneath them. Leadership dismisses all feedback and ideas. Records and reports on student registrations were consistently flawed over the almost two years I worked there, I had to time and time again defend my work. Pay is far below the cost of living of Denver and there are almost no opportunities for advancement. As a full time student, I  now make more from financial aid checks  than I ever did working here. Tuition benefits are nice, but what they strategically don't tell you is that tuition benefits  are taxed to the point that your paychecks are a few hundred dollars less. Turnover is exceptionally high as well. In the almost two years I was employed over 20 people left. Overall, this place is toxic and soul sucking and I don't hate anyone enough to ever recommend this place.

They don't internally hire, they outsource everything, and cross departmental communication is quite horrible.

Management also micromanages to the point where they listen in on 50-75% of your phone calls and read notes taken on calls. If the notes are not novel in length, you can expect to get talked to. Also, training doesn't cover things needed to keep other departments happy. Management is never present unless it's to reprimand, and they do not respect the ADA act and will write you up for showing symptoms of your disability (such as adverse reactions to medications and panic attacks, while they were well aware that an employee had a mental illness).  Also, the department I worked for did not follow the University's mission of men and women working together, or support the HR philosophy (or Catholic Church's for that matter) that women are going to have children that need taking care of.
